div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
I learn in this letter that Don Peter
of Arragon
comes this night to Messina.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
He is very near by this: he was not
three leagues off when I left him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
How many gentlemen have you lost
in this
action?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: But few of any sort, and none of name.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
A victory is twice itself when the
achiever
brings home full numbers. I find
here that Don Peter
hath bestowed much honor
on a young Florentine called
Claudio.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Much deserved on his part and
equally remembered
by Don Pedro; he hath
borne himself beyond the
promise of his age,
doing, in the figure of a lamb, the
feats of a
lion: he hath indeed better bettered expectation
than you must expect of me to tell you how.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
He hath an uncle here in Messina
will be very
much glad of it.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I have already delivered him letters,
and there
appears much joy in him; even so
much that joy could
not show itself modest
enough without a badge of
bitterness.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Did he break out into tears?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: In great measure.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
A kind overflow of kindness: there
are no faces
truer than those that are so
washed. How much better
is it to weep at joy
than to joy at weeping!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned
from
the wars or no?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I know none of that name, lady:
there was
none such in the army of any sort.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What is he that you ask for, niece?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
My cousin means Signior Benedick
of Padua.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
O, he's returned; and as pleasant as
ever he was.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
He set up his bills here in Messina
and challenged
Cupid at the flight; and my
uncle's fool, reading the
challenge, subscribed
for Cupid, and challenged him at
the bird-bolt.
I pray you, how many hath he killed and
eaten in these wars? But how many hath he
killed? for
indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick
too
much; but he'll be meet with you, I
doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You had musty victual, and he hath

holp to 
eat it: he is a very valiant trencherman;

he hath an 
excellent stomach.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: And a good soldier too, lady.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
And a good soldier to a lady: but
what is he
to a lord?

sp.speaker: Mess.
Beat.
sp.p:
It is so, indeed; he is no less than a
stuffed man:
but for the stuffing,���well, we
are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
You must not, sir, mistake my niece.
There is
a kind of merry war betwixt Signior
Benedick and her:
they never meet but there's
a skirmish of wit between
them.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our
last conflict
four of his five wits went halting
off, and now is
the whole man governed with
one: so that if he have
wit enough to keep
himself warm, let him bear it
for a difference
between himself and his horse; for it
is all the
wealth that he hath left, to be known a reasonable
creature. Who is his companion now? He
hath
every month a new sworn brother.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Very easily possible: he wears his
faith but as
the fashion of his hat; it ever
changes with the next block.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I see, lady, the gentleman is not in
your
books.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No; an he were, I would burn my
study. But,
I pray you, who is his companion?
Is there no young
squarer now that will make
a voyage with him to the
devil?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
He is most in the company of the
right noble
Claudio.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
O Lord, he will hang upon him like
a disease:
he is sooner caught than the pestilence,
and the taker
runs presently mad. God
help the noble Claudio! if he
have caught the
Benedick, it will cost him a thousand
pound ere a' be cured.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I will hold friends with you, lady.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Do, good friend.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You will never run mad, niece.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: No, not till a hot January.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Don Pedro is approached.
Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Good Signior Leonato, you are
come to meet
your trouble: the fashion of the
world is to avoid cost,
and you encounter it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Never came trouble to my house in
the likeness
of your grace: for trouble being
gone, comfort should
remain; but when you
depart from me, sorrow abides
and happiness
takes his leave.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
You embrace your charge too
willingly. I
think this is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Her mother hath many times told me so.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Signior Benedick, no; for then were
you a
child.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
You have it full, Benedick: we
may guess by
this what you are, being a man.
Truly, the lady fathers
herself. Be happy,
lady; for you are like an honorable
father.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If Signior Leonato be her father, she
would not
have his head on her shoulders for
all Messina, as like him
as she is.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I wonder that you will still be talking,
Signior
Benedick: nobody marks you.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
What, my dear Lady Disdain! are
you yet
living?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Is it possible disdain should die
while she
hath such meet food to feed it as
Signior Benedick?
Courtesy itself must convert
to disdain, if you come in
her presence.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it
is certain
I am loved of all ladies, only you
excepted: and
I would I could find in my
heart that I had not a hard
heart; for, truly, I love none.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
A dear happiness to women: they
would else
have been troubled with a pernicious
suitor. I thank
God and my cold blood, I
am of your humor for that: I
had rather hear
my dog bark at a crow than a man
swear he loves me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
God keep your ladyship still in that
mind!
so some gentleman or other shall 'scape
a predestinate
scratched face.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Scratching could not make it worse,
an 'twere
such a face as yours were.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
A bird of my tongue is better than a
beast of
yours.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I would my horse had the speed of
your tongue,
and so good a continuer. But
keep your way, i' God's
name; I have done.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You always end with a jade's trick:
I know
you of old.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
That is the sum of all, Leonato.
Signior Claudio
and Signior Benedick, my
dear friend Leonato hath
invited you all. I tell
him we shall stay here at the least
a month;
and he heartily prays some occasion may detain
us longer. I dare swear he is no hypocrite,
but
prays from his heart.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
If you swear, my lord, you shall not
be forsworn. [To Don John]
Let me bid you
welcome, my lord: being reconciled
to the
prince your brother, I owe you all
duty.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I thank you: I am not of many
words, but I
thank you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Please it your grace lead on?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Your hand, Leonato; we will
go together.
[Exeunt all except Benedick and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Benedick, didst thou note the
daughter of Signior
Leonato?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Is she not a modest young lady?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Do you question me, as an honest
man should
do, for my simple true judgement;
or would you have
me speak after my custom,
as being a professed tyrant
to their sex?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgement.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low
for a high
praise, too brown for a fair praise
and too little for a
great praise: only this
commendation I can afford her,
that were she
other than she is, she were unhandsome;
and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Thou thinkest I am in sport: I
pray thee tell me
truly how thou likest her.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Would you buy her, that you inquire
after
her?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Can the world buy such a jewel?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Yea, and a case to put it into. But
speak you this
with a sad brow? or do you
play the flouting Jack, to
tell us Cupid is a
good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare
carpenter?
Come, in what key shall a man take you, to
go in the song?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
In mine eye she is the sweetest lady
that ever
I looked on.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I can see yet without spectacles and
I see no
such matter: there's her cousin, an
she were not possessed
with a fury, exceeds
her as much in beauty as the first
of May doth
the last of December. But I hope you have
no
intent to turn husband, have you?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I would scarce trust myself, though
I had
sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Is't come to this? In faith, hath not
the world one
man but he will wear his cap
with suspicion? Shall I never
see a bachelor
of threescore again? Go to, i' faith;
an thou
wilt needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear
the print of it and sigh away Sundays. Look;
Don Pedro
is returned to seek you.
Re-enter DON PEDRO.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
What secret hath held you here,
that you followed
not to Leonato's?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I would your grace would constrain
me to
tell.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
You hear, Count Claudio: I can be
secret as a
dumb man; I would have you
think so; but, on my allegiance,
mark you this,
on my allegiance. He is in
love. With who?
now that is your grace's part. Mark
how short
his answer is;���With Hero, Leonato's short
daughter.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: If this were so, so were it uttered.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is
not so, nor 'twas
not so, but, indeed, God forbid
it should be so.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
If my passion change not shortly,
God forbid it
should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Amen, if you love her; for the
lady is very
well worthy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: By my troth, I speak my thought.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
And, by my two faiths and troths,
my lord, I
spoke mine.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: That I love her, I feel.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: That she is worthy, I know.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
That I neither feel how she should
be loved
nor know how she should be worthy,
is the
opinion that fire cannot melt out of me:
I will die in it at
the stake.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Thou wast ever an obstinate
heretic in the despite
of beauty.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
And never could maintain his part
but in the
force of his will.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
That a woman conceived me, I thank
her; that
she brought me up, I likewise give
her most humble
thanks: but that I will have
a recheat winded in my
forehead, or hang my
bugle in an invisible baldrick, all
women shall
pardon me. Because I will not do them the
wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the
right to
trust none; and the fine is, for the
which I may go the
finer, I will live a bachelor.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
I shall see thee, ere I die, look
pale with love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
With anger, with sickness, or with
hunger,
my lord, not with love: prove that
ever I lose more
blood with love than I will
get again with drinking,
pick out mine eyes
with a ballad-maker's pen and
hang me up at
the door of a brothel-house for the sign
of blind Cupid.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, if ever thou dost fall from
this faith,
thou wilt prove a notable argument.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a
cat and shoot
at me; and he that hits me, let
him be clapped on the shoulder,
and called Adam.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, as time shall try:
'In time the savage
bull doth bear the yoke.'

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
The savage bull may; but if ever
the sensible
Benedick bear it, pluck off the
bull's horns and set
them in my forehead:
and let me be vilely painted, and
in such great
letters as they write 'Here is a good horse
to
hire,' let them signify under my sign 'Here
you may
see Benedick the married man.'

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
If this should ever happen, thou
wouldst be
horn-mad.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all
his quiver in
Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I look for an earthquake too, then.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, you will temporize with
the hours. In
the meantime, good Signior
Bendick, repair to Leonato's:
commend me
to him and tell him I will not fail
him at supper;
for indeed he hath made great
preparation.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I have almost matter enough in me
for such an
embassage; and so I commit you���

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
To the tuition of God: From my
house, if I
had it,���

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
The sixth of July: Your loving
friend, Benedick.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Nay, mock not, mock not. The body
of your
discourse is sometime guarded with
fragments, and the
guards are but slightly
basted on neither: ere you flout
old ends any
further, examine your conscience: and so I
leave you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l:
My liege, your highness now may do me
good.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: No child but Hero; she's his only heir.
Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O, my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye,
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant, in their rooms
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Thou wilt be like a lover presently
And tire the hearer with a book of words.
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,
And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: How sweetly you do minister to love,
That know love's grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity.
Look, what will serve is fit; 'tis once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy.
I know we shall have revelling to-night:
I will assume thy part in some disguise
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after to her father will I break;
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.
In practice let us put it presently. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
How now, brother! Where is my
cousin, your son?
hath he provided this music?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
He is very busy about it. But, brother,
I can tell
you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are they good?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
As the event stamps them: but they
have a
good cover; they show well outward.
The prince and Count
Claudio, walking in a
thick-pleached alley in mine orchard,
were
much overheard by a man of mine: the
prince discovered
to Claudio that he loved my
niece your daughter
and meant to acknowledge
it this night in a dance;
and if he found
her accordant, he meant to take the
present
time by the top and instantly break with you
of it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Hath the fellow any wit that told
you this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
A good sharp fellow: I will send for
him; and
question him yourself.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
No, no; we will hold it as a dream
till it appear
itself: but I will acquaint my
daughter withal,
that she may be the better
prepared for an answer, if peradventure
this
be true. Go you and tell her of it. [Enter attendants.]
Cousins,
you know what you have
to do. O, I cry you mercy,
friend; go you
with me, and I will use your skill.
Good cousin,
have a care this busy time. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
What the good-year, my lord! why
are you
thus out of measure sad?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
There is no measure in the occasion
that breeds;
therefore the sadness is
without limit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You should hear reason.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
And when I have heard it, what
blessing
brings it?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
If not a present remedy, at least a
patient sufferance.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I wonder that thou, being, as thou
sayest thou art,
born under Saturn, goest about
to apply a moral medicine
to a mortifying
mischief. I cannot hide what I
am: I must be
sad when I have cause and smile at no
man's
jests, eat when I have stomach and wait for
no
man's leisure, sleep when I am drowsy and
tend on no
man's business, laugh when I am
merry and claw no man
in his humor.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Yea, but you must not make the full
show of this
till you may do it without controlment.
You have of
late stood out against
your brother, and he hath ta'en
you newly
into his grace; where it is impossible you
should take true root but by the fair weather
that you make
yourself: it is needful that
you frame the season for your
own harvest.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I had rather be a canker in a
hedge than a rose
in his grace, and it better
fits my blood to be disdained of
all than to
fashion a carriage to rob love from any: in
this,
though I cannot be said to be a flattering
honest man,
it must not be denied but I am a
plain-dealing villain. I
am trusted with a muzzle
and enfranchised with a clog;
therefore I
have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had
my mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty,
I would do
my liking: in the meantime let
me be that I am and
seek not to alter me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Can you make no use of your discontent?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I make all use of it, for I use it only.
Who comes here? Enter BORACHIO.
What news, Borachio?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
I came yonder from a great supper:
the prince
your brother is royally entertained
by Leonato: and I can
give you intelligence
of an intended marriage.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Will it serve for any model to
build mischief
on? What is he for a fool that
betroths himself to
unquietness?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Even he.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
A proper squire! And who, and
who? which way
looks he?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Marry, on Hero, the daughter and
heir of
Leonato.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
A very forward March-chick!
How came you
to this?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Being entertained for a perfumer, as
I was smoking
a musty room, comes me the
prince and Claudio,
hand in hand, in sad conference:
I whipt me behind the arras;
and
there heard it agreed upon that the prince
should
woo Hero for himself, and having obtained
her, give
her to Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Come, come, let us thither: this
may prove food
to my displeasure. That young
start-up hath all the glory
of my overthrow:
if I can cross him any way, I bless
myself
every way. You are both sure, and will assist
me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: To the death, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Let us to the great supper: their
cheer is the
greater that I am subdued. Would
the cook were of my
mind! Shall we go prove
what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l:
We'll wait upon your lordship.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Was not Count John here at supper?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I saw him not.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
How tartly that gentleman looks! I
never
can see him but I am heart-burned an
hour after.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
He were an excellent man that were
made
just in the midway between him and
Benedick: the one
is too like an image and
says nothing, and the other too
like my lady's
eldest son, evermore tattling.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Then half Signior Benedick's tongue
in Count
John's mouth, and half Count John's
melancholy in Signior
Benedick's face,���

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
With a good leg and a good foot,
uncle, and
money enough in his purse, such a
man would win any
woman in the world, if
a' could get her good-will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
By my troth, niece, thou wilt never
get thee a
husband, if thou be so shrewd of
thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In faith, she's too curst.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Too curst is more than curst: I shall
lessen God's
sending that way; for it is said,
'God sends a curst cow
short horns;' but to
a cow too curst he sends none.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
So, by being too curst, God will send you no
horns.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Just, if he send me no husband; for
the which
blessing I am at him upon my knees
every morning and
evening. Lord, I could not
endure a husband with a
beard on his face:
I had rather lie in the woollen.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
You may light on a husband that
hath no
beard.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
What should I do with him? dress
him in
my apparel and make him my waiting-
gentlewoman? He
that hath a beard is more
than a youth, and he that hath
no beard is
less than a man: and he that is more than a
youth is not for me, and he that is less than
a man, I am
not for him: therefore I will
even take sixpence in earnest
of the bear-ward,
and lead his apes into hell.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Well, then, go you into hell?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No, but to the gate; and there will
the devil
meet me, like an old cuckold, with
horns on his head,
and say 'Get you to
heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven;
here's
no place for you maids:' so deliver I up my
apes,
and away to Saint Peter for the heavens;
he shows me
where the bachelors sit, and
there live we as merry as
the day is long.

div2.sp:
Ant.[To Hero]
Well, niece, I trust you
will be ruled by your
father.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to
make curtsy
and say 'Father, as it please
you.' But yet for all that, cousin, let
him be
a handsome fellow, or else make another
curtsy
and say 'Father, as it please me.'

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Well, niece, I hope to see you one
day fitted
with a husband.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Not till God make men of some other
metal
than earth. Would it not grieve a woman
to be overmastered
with a piece of valiant
dust? to make an account of
her life to a clod
of wayward marl? No, uncle, I'll none:
Adam's sons are my brethren; and, truly, I
hold it a sin
to match in my kindred.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Daughter, remember what I told
you: if the
prince do solicit you in that kind,
you know your
answer.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
The fault will be in the music, cousin,
if you
be not wooed in good time: if the
prince be too important,
tell him there is measure
in every thing and so dance
out the answer.
For, hear me, Hero: wooing, wedding,
and
repenting, is as a Scotch jig, a measure,
and a cinque
pace: the first suit is hot and
hasty, like a Scotch jig,
and full as fantastical;
the wedding, mannerly-modest,
as a measure,
full of state and ancientry; and then comes
repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into
the cinque pace
faster and faster, till he sink
into his grave.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I have a good eye, uncle; I can see
a church
by daylight.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
The revellers are entering, brother:
make good
room. [All put on their masks.
Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA, and others, masked.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
So you walk softly and look sweetly
and say
nothing, I am yours for the walk; and
especially when I
walk away.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: With me in your company?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I may say so, when I please.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: And when please you to say so?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
When I like your favor; for God
defend the
lute should be like the case!

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
Hero.
sp.p:
Why, then, your visor should be
thatched.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Speak low, if you speak love. [Drawing her aside.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Well, I would you did like me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
Balth.
sp.p: Which is one?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I say my prayers aloud.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p:
I love you the better: the hearers
may cry, Amen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: God match me with a good dancer!

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
And God keep him out of my sight
when the
dance is done! Answer, clerk.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: No more words: the clerk is answered.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
I know you well enough; you are
Signior
Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
I know you by the waggling of your
head.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
You could never do him so ill-well,
unless
you were the very man. Here's his dry
hand up and down:
you are he, you are he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
Come, come, do you think I do not
know
you by your excellent wit? can virtue
hide itself? Go
to, mum, you are he: graces
will appear, and there's
an end.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you not tell me who told you so?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: No, you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Not now.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
That I was disdainful, and that I had
my good
wit out of the 'Hundred Merry
Tales:'���well, this was Signior
Benedick that said so.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: What's he?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am sure you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Not I, believe me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Did he never make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I pray you, what is he?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Why, he is the prince's jester: a very
dull fool;
only his gift is in devising impossible
slanders: none
but libertines delight in
him; and the commendation is
not in his wit,
but in his villany; for he both pleases
men
and angers them, and then they laugh at him
and
beat him. I am sure he is in the fleet: I
would he had
boarded me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
When I know the gentleman, I'll tell
him what
you say.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Do, do: he'll but break a comparison
or two
on me; which, peradventure not
marked or not laughed
at, strikes him into
melancholy; and then there's a partridge
wing
saved, for the fool will eat no supper that
night. [Music.] We must follow the leaders.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: In every good thing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will
leave them
at the next turning. [Dance. Then exeunt all except Don John, Borachio, and Claudio.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Sure my brother is amorous on
Hero and hath
withdrawn her father to break
with him about it. The
ladies follow her and
but one visor remains.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
And that is Claudio: I know him by
his
bearing.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Are not you Signior Benedick?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You know me well; I am he.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Signior, you are very near my
brother in his
love: he is enamored on Hero;
I pray you, dissuade him
from her: she is no
equal for his birth: you may do the
part of
an honest man in it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: How know you he loves her?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I heard him swear his affection.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
So did I too; and he swore he would
marry her
to-night.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Come, let us to the banquet. [Exeunt Don John and Borachio.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thus answer I in name of Benedick,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself.
Friendship is constant in all other things
Save in the office and affairs of love:
Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues;
Let every eye negotiate for itself
And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch
Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
This is an accident of hourly proof,

Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!
Re-enter BENEDICK.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Count Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Yea, the same.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Come, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Even to the next willow, about your
own business,
county. What fashion will you
wear the garland
of? about your neck, like
an usurer's chain? or
under your arm, like a
lieutenant's scarf? You must
wear it one way,
for the prince hath got your Hero.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I wish him joy of her.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Why, that's spoken like an honest
drovier: so
they sell bullocks. But did you
think the prince would
have served you thus?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I pray you, leave me,

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Ho! now you strike like the blind
man: 'twas the
boy that stole your meat, and
you'll beat the post.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: If it will not be, I'll leave you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he
creep into
sedges. But that my Lady Beatrice
should know me, and
not know me! The
prince's fool! Ha? It may be I go
under that
title because I am merry. Yea, but so I am
apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed:
it is the
base, though bitter, disposition of
Beatrice that puts
the world into her person,
and so gives me out. Well, I'll
be revenged as I may.
Re-enter DON PEDRO.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Now, signior, where's the count?
did you
see him?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Troth, my lord, I have played the
part of Lady
Fame. I found him here as melancholy
as a lodge in a
warren: I told him,
and I think I told him true, that your
grace
had got the good will of this young lady; and
I offered
him my company to a willow-tree,
either to make him a
garland, as being forsaken,
or to bind him up a rod, as being
worthy to be whipped.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: To be whipped! What's his fault?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
The flat transgression of a school-boy,
who,
being overjoyed with finding a birds'
nest, shows it his
companion, and he steals it.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression?
The
transgression is in the stealer.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Yet it had not been amiss the rod
had been
made, and the garland too; for the
garland he might have
worn himself, and the
rod he might have bestowed on
you, who, as
I take it, have stolen his birds' nest.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
I will but teach them to sing, and
restore them
to the owner.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If their singing answer your saying,
by my faith,
you say honestly.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel
to you: the
gentleman that danced with
her told her she is much
wronged by you.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
O, she misused me past the endurance
of a block!
an oak but with one green
leaf on it would have answered
her; my very
visor began to assume life and scold
with her.
She told me, not thinking I had been myself,
that I was the prince's jester, that I was duller
than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest
with such impossible
conveyance upon me
that I stood like a man at a
mark, with a
whole army shooting at me. She speaks
poniards,
and every word stabs: if her breath
were
as terrible as her terminations, there
were no living near
her; she would infect to
the north star. I would not
marry her, though
she were endowed with all that Adam
had
left him before he transgressed: she would
have made
Hercules have turned spit, yea, and
have cleft his club to
make the fire too. Come,
talk not of her: you shall find
her the infernal
Ate in good apparel. I would to God
some
scholar would conjure her; for certainly, while
she
is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as
in a sanctuary;
and people sin upon purpose,
because they would go
thither; so, indeed, all
disquiet, horror and perturbation
follows her.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Look, here she comes. Re-enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Will your grace command me any
service to
the world's end? I will go on the
slightest errand now
to the Antipodes that you
can devise to send me on; I
will fetch you a
tooth-picker now from the furthest inch
of
Asia, bring you the length of Prester John's
foot, fetch
you a hair off the great Cham's
beard, do you any embassage
to the Pigmies,
rather than hold three words'
conference with
this harpy. You have no employment
for me?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: None, but to desire your good company.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
O God, sir, here's a dish I love not:
I cannot endure
my Lady Tongue. [Exit.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Come, lady, come; you have
lost the heart of
Signior Benedick.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Indeed, my lord, he lent it me
awhile; and I
gave him use for it, a double
heart for his single one: marry,
once before
he won it of me with false dice, therefore
your
grace may well say I have lost it.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
You have put him down, lady,
you have put
him down.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
So I would not he should do me, my
lord, lest
I should prove the mother of fools.
I have brought
Count Claudio, whom you sent
me to seek.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Why, how now, count! wherefore
are you sad?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Not sad, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: How then? sick?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Neither, my lord.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
The count is neither sad, nor sick,
nor merry,
nor well; but civil count, civil as
an orange, and something
of that jealous complexion.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
I' faith, lady, I think your blazon
to be true;
though, I'll be sworn, if he be so,
his conceit is false.
Here, Claudio, I have
wooed in thy name, and fair Hero
is won: I
have broke with her father, and his good will
obtained: name the day of marriage, and God
give
thee joy!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Count, take of me my daughter, and
with her
my fortunes: his grace hath made
the match, and all grace
say Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Silence is the perfectest herald of
joy: I were
but little happy, if I could say how
much. Lady, as you
are mine, I am yours: I
give away myself for you and
dote upon the exchange.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot,
stop his mouth
with a kiss, and let not him
speak neither.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool,
it keeps
on the windy side of care. My cousin
tells him in his ear
that he is in her heart.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And so she doth, cousin.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes
every one
to the world but I, and I am sunburnt;
I may sit in a corner
and cry heigh-ho
for a husband!

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I would rather have one of your
father's getting.
Hath your grace ne'er a
brother like you? Your father
got excellent
husbands, if a maid could come by them.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Will you have me, lady?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No, my lord, unless I might have
another for
working-days: your grace is too
costly to wear every
day. But, I beseech your
grace, pardon me: I was born
to speak all
mirth and no matter.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Your silence most offends me,
and to be merry
best becomes you; for, out of
question, you were born
in a merry hour.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No, sure, my lord, my mother cried;

but then 
there was a star danced, and under

that was I born. Cousins, 
God give you joy!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Niece, will you look to those things
I told
you of?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I cry you mercy, uncle. By your
grace's pardon.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l:
By my troth, a pleasant-spirited
lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
There's little of the melancholy element
in her,
my lord: she is never sad but
when she sleeps, and not
ever sad then; for I
have heard my daughter say, she
hath often
dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself
with
laughing.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
She cannot endure to hear tell
of a husband.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O, by no means: she mocks all her
wooers
out of suit.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
She were an excellent wife for
Benedick.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O Lord, my lord, if they were but a
week
married, they would talk themselves mad.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
County Claudio, when mean you
to go to
church?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
To-morrow, my lord: time goes on
crutches
till love have all his rites.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Not till Monday, my dear son, which
is
hence a just seven-night; and a time too
brief, too, to have
all things answer my mind.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Come, you shake the head at so
long a breathing:
but, I warrant thee, Claudio,
the time shall not go
dully by us. I will
in the interim undertake one of Hercules'
labors;
which is, to bring Signior Benedick and
the
Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection
the one with
the other. I would fain have it a
match, and I doubt not
but to fashion it, if
you three will but minister such assistance
as
I shall give you direction.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
My lord, I am for you, though it cost
me
ten nights' watchings.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And I, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: And you too, gentle Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
I will do any modest office, my lord,
to help
my cousin to a good husband.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
And Benedick is not the unhopefullest
husband
that I know. Thus far can I
praise him; he is of a noble
strain, of approved
valor and confirmed honesty. I will
teach you how to humor your cousin, that she
shall fall
in love with Benedick; and I, with
your two helps, will
so practise on Benedick
that, in despite of his quick
wit and his queasy
stomach, he shall fall in love with
Beatrice.
If we can do this, Cupid is no longer an
archer:
his glory shall be ours, for we are the
only love-gods.
Go in with me, and I will tell
you my drift. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
It is so; the Count Claudio shall
marry the daughter
of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Any bar, any cross, any impediment
will be
medicinable to me: I am sick
in displeasure to him, and
whatsoever comes
athwart his affection ranges evenly
with mine.
How canst thou cross this marriage?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly
that no
dishonesty shall appear in me.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: Show me briefly how.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
I think I told your lordship a year
since, how
much I am in the favor of Margaret,
the waiting gentlewoman
to Hero.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
I can, at any unseasonable instant of
the night,
appoint her to look out at her lady's
chamber-window.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
What life is in that, to be the
death of this
marriage?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
The poison of that lies in you to
temper. Go
you to the prince your brother;
spare not to tell him that
he hath wronged his
honor in marrying the renowned
Claudio���
whose estimation do you mightily hold up���to
a
contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: What proof shall I make of that?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Proof enough to misuse the prince,
to vex
Claudio, to undo Hero and kill Leonato.
Look you for any
other issue?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Only to despite them, I will endeavor any
thing.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Go, then; find me a meet hour to
draw Don
Pedro and the Count Claudio alone:
tell them that you
know that Hero loves me;
intend a kind of zeal both
to the prince and
Claudio, as,���in love of your brother's
honor,
who hath made this match, and his friend's
reputation,
who is thus like to be cozened with
the semblance
of a maid,���that you have discovered
thus. They will scarcely
believe this
without trial: offer them instances; which
shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at
her
chamber-window, hear me call Margaret
Hero, hear
Margaret term me Claudio; and
bring them to see this
the very night before
the intended wedding,���for in the
meantime I
will so fashion the matter that Hero shall
be
absent,���and there shall appear such seeming
truth of
Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall
be called assurance
and all the preparation
overthrown.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Grow this to what adverse issue
it can, I will
put it in practice. Be cunning in
the working this, and
thy fee is a thousand
ducats.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Be you constant in the accusation,
and my cunning
shall not shame me.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I will presently go learn their day
of
marriage. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Boy!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Signior?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In my chamber-window lies a book:
bring it
hither to me in the orchard.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am here already, sir.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I know that; but I would have thee
hence, and
here again.[Exit Boy.] I do much
wonder that one man, seeing
how much another
man is a fool when he dedicates his
behaviors
to love, will, after he hath laughed
at such
shallow follies in others, become the
argument of his
own scorn by falling in love:
and such a man is Claudio.
I have known
when there was no music with him but
the
drum and the fife; and now had he rather
hear the
tabor and the pipe: I have known
when he would have
walked ten mile a-foot to
see a good armor; and now will
he lie ten
nights awake, carving the fashion of a new
doublet.
He was wont to speak plain and to
the purpose, like
an honest man and a soldier;
and now is he turned orthography;
his words
are a very fantastical banquet, just so
many
strange dishes. May I be so converted and see
with
these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I
will not be
sworn but love may transform
me to an oyster; but I'll
take my oath on it,
till he have made an oyster of me, he
shall
never make me such a fool. One woman is
fair, yet
I am well; another is wise, yet I am
well; another virtuous,
yet I am well; but till
all graces be in one woman,
one woman shall
not come in my grace. Rich she shall
be, that's
certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'11
never
cheapen her; fair, or I'll never look on
her; mild,
or come not near me; noble, or
not I for an angel; of
good discourse, an excellent
musician, and her hair shall
be of what
color it please God. Ha! the prince and
Monsieur
Love! I will hide me in the arbor. [Withdraws.
Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Come, shall we hear this music?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,
As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O, very well, my lord: the music ended,
We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth. Enter BALTHASAR with Music.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice
To slander music any more than once.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: It is the witness still of excellency
To put a strange face on his own perfection.
I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,
Yet will he swear he loves.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Now, pray thee, come;
Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: Note this before my notes;
There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;
Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing. [Air.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Now, divine air! now is his soul
ravished! Is it
not strange that sheeps' guts
should hale souls out of
men's bodies? Well,
a horn for my money, when all's
done.
The Song.
Balth.
Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in sea and one on shore,
To one thing constant never:
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blithe and bonny,
Converting all your sounds of woe
Into Hey nonny, nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,
Of dumps so dull and heavy;
The fraud of men was ever so,
Since summer first was leavy:
Then sigh not so, &c.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: By my troth, a good song.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: And an ill singer, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest
well enough for a
shift.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
An he had been a dog that should
have howled
thus, they would have hanged
him: and I pray God his
bad voice bode no
mischief. I had as lief have heard
the night-
raven, come what plague could have come
after
it.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar?
I pray
thee, get us some excellent
music; for to-morrow night
we would have it
at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: The best I can, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Do so: farewell.[Exit Balthasar.]
Come hither, Leonato. What
was it
you told me of to-day, that your niece Beatrice
was in love with Signior Benedick?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
O, ay: stalk on, stalk on; the fowl
sits. I did never
think that lady would have
loved any man.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
No, nor I neither; but most wonderful
that she
should so dote on Signior Benedick,
whom she hath in
all outward behaviors
seemed ever to abhor.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Is't possible? Sits the wind in that
corner?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell
what to
think of it but that she loves him with
an enraged affection:
it is past the infinite of
thought.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: May be she doth but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Faith, like enough.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O God, counterfeit! There was
never counterfeit
of passion came so near the
life of passion as she discovers
it.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
What effects, my lord? She will sit
you, you
heard my daughter tell you how.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: She did, indeed.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
How, how, I pray you? You
amaze me: I would
have thought her spirit
had been invincible against all
assaults of affection.

sp.speaker: Leon.
Bene.
sp.p:
I should think this a gull, but that
the white-bearded
fellow speaks it: knavery
cannot, sure, hide
himself in such reverence.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Hath she made her affection
known to
Benedick?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
No; and swears she never will:
that's her
torment.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter
says: 'Shall
I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered
him with scorn,
write to him that I
love him?'

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
This says she now when she is beginning
to
write to him; for she'll be up twenty
times a night, and
there will she sit in her
smock till she have writ a sheet
of paper: my
daughter tells us all.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I
remember
a pretty jest your daughter told us
of.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O, when she had writ it and was
reading it over,
she found Benedick and Beatrice
between the sheet?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O, she tore the letter into a thousand
halfpence;
railed at herself, that she should
be so immodest to write
to one that she knew
would flout her: 'I measure him,'
says she,
'by my own spirit; for I should flout him, if
he
writ to me; yea, though I love him, I
should.'

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Then down upon her knees she
falls, weeps,
sobs, beats her heart, tears her
hair, prays, curses;
'O sweet Benedick! God
give me patience!'

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
She doth indeed; my daughter says
so: and the
ecstasy hath so much overborne
her that my daughter is
sometime afeard she
will do a desperate outrage to herself:
it is
very true.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
It were good that Benedick knew
of it by some
other, if she will not discover it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
To what end? He would make but
a sport of it
and torment the poor lady worse.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
An he should, it were an alms to
hang him.
She's an excellent sweet lady; and,
out of all suspicion,
she is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And she is exceeding wise.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
In every thing but in loving
Benedick.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating
in
so tender a body, we have ten proofs
to one that blood
hath the victory. I am sorry
for her, as I have just cause,
being her uncle
and her guardian.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
I would she had bestowed this
dotage on
me: I would have daffed all other
respects and made her
half myself. I pray you,
tell Benedick of it, and hear
what a' will say.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Were it good, think you?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Hero thinks surely she will die; for
she says she
will die, if he love her not, and
she will die, ere she
make her love known, and
she will die, if he woo her,
rather than she
will bate one breath of her accustomed
crossness.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
She doth well: if she should
make tender of her
love, 'tis very possible
he'll scorn it; for the man, as you
know all,
hath a contemptible spirit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: He is a very proper man.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
He hath indeed a good outward
happiness.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
He doth indeed show some
sparks that are like
wit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And I take him to be valiant.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
As Hector, I assure you: and in
the managing of
quarrels you may say he is
wise; for either he avoids
them with great
discretion, or undertakes them with a most
Christian-like fear.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
If he do fear God, a' must necessarily
keep
peace: if he break the peace, he ought
to enter into a
quarrel with fear and trembling.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
And so will he do; for the man
doth fear God,
howsoever it seems not in him
by some large jests he
will make. Well, I am
sorry for your niece. Shall we go
seek Benedick,
and tell him of her love?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Never tell him, my lord: let her
wear it out
with good counsel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Nay, that's impossible: she may
wear her heart
out first.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, we will hear further of it
by your daughter:
let it cool the while. I love
Benedick well; and I
could wish he would
modestly examine himself, to see
how much
he is unworthy so good a lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
My lord, will you walk? dinner is
ready.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
If he do not dote on her upon this,
I will never
trust my expectation.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Let there be the same net spread
for her; and
that must your daughter and her
gentlewoman carry.
The sport will be, when
they hold one an opinion of another's
dotage,
and no such matter: that's the scene that I
would see, which will be merely a dumb-show.
Let us
send her to call him in to dinner. [Exeunt Don Pedro, Claudio, and Leonato.

div2.sp:
Bene.[Coming forward]
This can be no
trick: the conference was sadly
borne. They
have the truth of this from Hero. They seem
to pity the lady: it seems her affections have
their full bent.
Love me! why, it must be requited.
I hear how I
am censured: they say
I will bear myself proudly, if I
perceive the
love come from her: they say too that she
will rather die than give any sign of affection.
I did never
think to marry: I must not seem
proud: happy are
they that hear their detractions
and can put them to
mending. They say
the lady is fair; 'tis a truth, I can
bear them
witness; and virtuous; 'tis so, I cannot reprove
it; and wise, but for loving me; by my
troth, it is
no addition to her wit, nor no great
argument of her
folly, for I will be horribly in
love with her. I may choice
have some odd
quirks and remnants of wit broken
on me, because
I have railed so long against marriage:
but doth not the appetite alter? a man loves
the meat in
his youth that he cannot endure
in his age. Shall quips
and sentences and these
paper bullets of the brain awe
a man from
the career of his humor? No, the world
must
be peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor,
I
did not think I should live till I were
married. Here comes
Beatrice. By this day!
she's a fair lady: I do spy some
marks of love
in her.
Enter BEATRICE.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Against my will I am sent to bid you
come in to
dinner.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your
pains.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I took no more pains for those thanks
than
you take pains to thank me: if it had
been painful, I
would not have come.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: You take pleasure then in the message?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Yea, just so much as you may take
upon a knife's
point and choke a daw withal.
You have no stomach,
signior: fare you well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to
bid you come
in to dinner;' there's a double
meaning in that. 'I took
no more pains for
those thanks than you took pains
to thank me;'
that's as much as to say, Any pains that I
take
for you is as easy as thanks. If I do not take
pity
of her, I am a villain; if I do not love her,
I am a Jew. I
will go get her picture. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE I

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor;
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the prince and Claudio:
Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse
Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter, like favorites,
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,
To listen our purpose. This is thy office;
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit:
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it. [Approaching the bower.
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggerds of the rock.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: So says the prince and my newtrothed lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endeared.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sure, I think so;
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured,
But she would spell him backward: if fairfaced,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antique,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agate very vilely cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: No; rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with: one doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.
She can not be so much without true judgement���
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have���as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted my dear Claudio.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valor,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l:
She's limed, I warrant you:
we have caught her, madam.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: If it proves so, then loving goes by haps:
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps. [Exeunt Hero and Ursula.

div2.sp:
Beat. [Coming forward]
What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.[Exit.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
I do but stay till your marriage
be consummate,
and then go I toward Arragon.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I'll bring you thither, my lord, if
you'll vouchsafe
me.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Nay, that would be as great a
soil in the new
gloss of your marriage as to
show a child his new coat
and forbid him to
wear it. I will only be bold with
Benedick for
his company; for, from the crown of his
head
to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth: he hath
twice
or thrice cut Cupid's bow-string and the
little hangman
dare not shoot at him; he hath
a heart as sound as a bell
and his tongue is
the clapper, for what his heart thinks
his tongue
speaks.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: So say I: methinks you are sadder.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I hope he be in love.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Hang him, truant! there's no
true drop of blood
in him, to be truly touched
with love: if he be sad, he wants
money.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: I have the toothache.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Draw it.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Hang it!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
You must hang it first, and draw it
afterwards.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: What! sigh for the toothache?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Where is but a humor or a worm.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Well, every one can master a grief
but he
that has it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Yet say I, he is in love.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
There is no appearance of fancy
in him, unless
it be a fancy that he hath to
strange disguises; as, to be a
Dutchman today,
a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the shape
of two countries at once, as, a German from
the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard
from the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he
have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he
hath, he
is no fool for fancy, as you would
have it appear
he is.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
If he be not in love with some
woman, there
is no believing old signs: a'
brushes his hat o' mornings;
what should that bode?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Hath any man seen him at the
barber's?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
No, but the barber's man hath been
seen with
him, and the old ornament of his
cheek hath already
stuffed tennis-balls.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Indeed, he looks younger than he
did, by the
loss of a beard.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Nay, a' rubs himself with civet:
can you smell
him out by that?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
That's as much as to say, the sweet
youth's in
love.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
The greatest note of it is his
melancholy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l:
And when was he wont to wash his
face?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Yea, or to paint himself? for the
which, I hear
what they say of him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is
now crept
into a lute-string and now governed
by stops.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Indeed, that tells a heavy tale
for him: conclude, conclude
he is in love.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Nay, but I know who loves him.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
That would I know too: I warrant
one that
knows him not.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in
despite of all,
dies for him.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
She shall be buried with her face
upwards.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Yet is this no charm for the toothache.
Old signior,
walk aside with me: I have
studied eight or nine
wise words to speak to
you, which these hobby-horses
must not hear. [Exeunt Benedick and Leonato.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
For my life, to break with him
about Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret
have by this
played their parts with Beatrice;
and then the two bears
will not bite one another
when they meet.
Enter DON JOHN.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p: My lord and brother, God save you!

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: Good den, brother.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
If your leisure served, I would
speak with you.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: In private?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
If it please you: yet Count
Claudio may hear;
for what I would speak of
concerns him.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: What's the matter?

div2.sp:
D. John. [To Claudio]
Means your lordship
to be married
to-morrow?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: You know he does.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I know not that, when he knows
what I know.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
If there be any impediment, I pray
you discover
it.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
You may think I love you not:
let that appear
hereafter, and aim better at me
by that I now will manifest.
For my brother,
I think he holds you well, and in
dearness of
heart hath holp to effect your ensuing
marriage,���
surely suit ill spent and labor ill bestowed.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I came hither to tell you; and,
circumstances
shortened, for she has been too
long a talking of, the
lady is disloyal.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Who, Hero?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
Even she; Leonato's Hero, your
Hero, every
man's Hero.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Disloyal?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
The word is too good to paint out
her wickedness;
I could say she were worse:
think you of a worse
title, and I will fit her to
it. Wonder not till further warrant:
go but
with me to-night, you shall see her chamberwindow
entered, even the night before her
wedding-day:
if you love her then, to-morrow
wed her; but it
would better fit your honor to
change your mind.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: May this be so?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: I will not think it.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
If you dare not trust that you see,
confess not
that you know: if you will follow
me, I will show you
enough; and when you
have seen more and heard more,
proceed
accordingly.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
If I see any thing to-night why I
should not
marry her to-morrow, in the congregation,
where I should
wed, here will I
shame her.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
And, as I wooed for thee to obtain
her, I will
join with thee to disgrace her.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
I will disparage her no farther
till you are my
witness: bear it coldly but
till midnight, and let the issue
show itself.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: O day untowardly turned!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O mischief strangely thwarting!

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.p:
O plague right well prevented!
so will you
say when you have seen the sequel. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: Are you good men and true?

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Yea, or else it were pity but they
should suffer
salvation, body and soul.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Nay, that were a punishment too
good for
them, if they should have any allegiance
in them, being
chosen for the prince's watch.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Well, give them their charge, neighbor
Dogberry.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
First, who think you the most desartless
man
to be constable?

sp.speaker: First Watch.
sp.p:
Hugh Otecake, sir, or George
Seacole; for
they can write and read.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Come hither, neighbor Seacole. God
hath
blessed you with a good name: to be a
well-favored man
is the gift of fortune: but
to write and read comes by
nature.

sp.speaker: Sec. Watch.
sp.p: Both which, master constable,���

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
You have: I knew it would be your
answer.
Well, for your favor, sir, why, give
God thanks, and make
no boast of it; and for
your writing and reading, let that
appear when
there is no need of such vanity. You are
thought here to be the most senseless and fit
man for the
constable of the watch; therefore
bear you the lantern.
This is your charge:
you shall comprehend all
vagrom men; you
are to bid any man stand, in the prince's
name.

sp.speaker: Sec. Watch.
sp.p: How if a' will not stand?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why, then, take no note of him, but
let him go;
and presently call the rest of the
watch together and
thank God you are rid of
a knave.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
If he will not stand when he is bidden,
he is
none of the prince's subjects.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
True, and they are to meddle with
none but
the prince's subjects. You shall also
make no noise in the
streets; for, for the watch
to babble and to talk is most
tolerable and not
to be endured.

sp.speaker: Watch.
Dog.
sp.p:
Why, you speak like an ancient and
most quiet
watchman; for I cannot see how
sleeping should offend:
only, have a care that
your bills be not stolen. Well, you
are to call
at all the ale-houses, and bid those that are
drunk get them to bed.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: How if they will not?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why, then, let them alone till they
are sober: if
they make you not then the better
answer, you may say
they are not the men
you took them for.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
If you meet a thief, you may suspect
him, by
virtue of your office, to be no true
man; and, for such
kind of men, the less you
meddle or make with them,
why, the more is
for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
If we know him to be a thief, shall
we not
lay hands on him?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Truly, by your office, you may; but
I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled:
the most peaceable way
for you, if you do take
a thief, is to let him show himself
what he is
and steal out of your company.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
You have been always called a merciful
man, partner.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Truly, I would not hang a dog by my
will, much
more a man who hath any honesty
in him.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
If you hear a child cry in the night,
you must
call to the nurse and bid her still it.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
How if the nurse be asleep and
will not
hear us?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why, then, depart in peace, and let
the child
wake her with crying; for the ewe
that will not hear
her lamb when it baes will
never answer a calf when
he bleats.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
This is the end of the charge:���you,
constable,
are to present the prince's own person:
if you meet the
prince in the night, you
may stay him.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Nay, by'r lady, that I think a'
cannot.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Five shillings to one on't, with any
man that
knows the statutes, he may stay him:
marry, not without
the prince be willing; for,
indeed, the watch ought to
offend no man; and
it is an offence to stay a man against
his will.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.l: By'r lady, I think it be so.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good
night: an there by
any matter of weight
chances, call up me: keep your
fellows' counsels
and your own; and good night.
Come,
neighbor.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
Well, masters, we hear our charge:
let us go
sit here upon the church-bench till
two, and then all to
bed.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
One word more, honest neighbors. I
pray you,
watch about Signior Leonato's door;
for the wedding being
there to-morrow, there
is a great coil to-night.
Adieu: be vigitant, I
beseech you. [Exeunt Dogberry and Verges.
Enter BORACHIO and CONRADE.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: What, Conrade!

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Conrade, I say!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Here, man; I am at thy elbow.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Mass, and my elbow itched; I
thought there would
a scab follow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I will owe thee an answer for that:
and now
forward with thy tale.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Stand thee close, then, under this
pent-house, for it
drizzles rain; and I will, like
a true drunkard, utter all to
thee.

div2.sp:
Watch. [Aside]
Some treason, masters: yet
stand close.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Therefore know I have earned of
Don John a
thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Is it possible that any villany should
be so dear?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Thou shouldst rather ask if it were
possible any
villany should be so rich; for
when rich villains have
need of poor ones,
poor ones may make what price
they will.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
That shows thou art unconfirmed.
Thou knowest
that the fashion of a doublet,
or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing
to a man.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes, it is apparel.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: I mean, the fashion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Tush! I may as well say the fool's
the fool. But
seest thou not what a deformed
thief this fashion is?

div2.sp:
Watch. [Aside]
I know that Deformed; a'
has been a vile thief
this seven year; a' goes
up and down like a gentleman:
I remember
his name.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Didst thou not hear somebody?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: No; 'twas the vane on the house.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed
thief
this fashion is? how giddily a'
turns about all the hot
bloods between fourteen
and five-and-thirty? sometimes
fashioning
them like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reeky
painting,
sometime like god Bel's priests in the old
church-window, sometime like the shaven Hercules
in the
smirched worm-eaten tapestry,
where his codpiece
seems as massy as his club?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
All this I see; and I see that the
fashion wears out
more apparel than the man.
But art not thou thyself
giddy with the fashion
too, that thou hast shifted out of
thy tale into
telling me of the fashion?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Not so, neither: but know that I
have to-night
wooed Margaret, the Lady
Hero's gentlewoman, by the
name of Hero:
she leans me out at her mistress' chamber-
window,
bids me a thousand times good night,
���I tell
this tale vilely:���I should first tell
thee how the prince,
Claudio and my master,
planted and placed and possessed
by my master
Don John, saw afar off in the orchard this
amiable encounter.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Two of them did, the prince and
Claudio; but the
devil my master knew she
was Margaret; and partly by
his oaths, which
first possessed them, partly by the dark
night,
which did deceive them, but chiefly by my villany,
which did confirm any slander that Don
John had
made, away went Claudio enraged;
swore he would
meet her, as he was appointed,
next morning at the temple,
and there, before
the whole congregation, shame her
with what
he saw o'er night and send her home again
without a husband.

sp.speaker: First Watch.
sp.p:
We charge you, in the prince's
name, stand!

sp.speaker: Sec. Watch.
sp.p:
Call up the right master constable.
We have
here recovered the most dangerous
piece of lechery that
ever was known in
the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: First Watch.
sp.p:
And one Deformed is one of
them: I know
him; a' wears a lock.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Masters, masters,���

sp.speaker: Sec. Watch.
sp.p:
You'll be made bring Deformed
forth, I warrant
you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Masters,���

sp.speaker: First Watch.
sp.p:
Never speak: we charge you
let us obey
you to go with us.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
We are like to prove a goodly commodity,
being
taken up of these men's bills.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
A commodity in question, I warrant
you. Come,
we'll obey you. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice,
and desire
her to rise.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: I will, lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: And bid her come hither.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p: Well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Troth, I think your other rabato
were better.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
By my troth, 's not so good; and I
warrant your
cousin will say so.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
My cousin's a fool, and thou art another:
I'll
wear none but this.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
I like the new tire within excellently,
if the
hair were a thought browner; and your
gown's a most
rare fashion, i' faith. I saw the
Duchess of Milan's
gown that they praise so.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: O, that exceeds, they say.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
By my troth, 's but a night-gown in
respect of
yours: cloth o' gold, and cuts, and
laced with silver, set with
pearls, down sleeves,
side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne
with
a bluish tinsel: but for a fine, quaint, graceful
and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten on't.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
God give me joy to wear it! for my
heart is
exceedingly heavy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
'Twill be heavier soon by the weight
of a
man.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Of what, lady? of speaking honorably?
Is
not marriage honorable in a beggar?
Is not your lord
honorable without marriage?
I think you would have
me say, 'saving your
reverence, a husband:' and bad thinking
do
not wrest true speaking, I'll offend nobody: is
there any harm in 'the heavier for a husband'?
None, I
think, an it be the right husband
and the right wife:
otherwise 'tis light,
and not heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice
else;
here she comes.
Enter BEATRICE.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Good morrow, coz.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
Why, how now? do you speak in the
sick tune?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Clap's into 'Light o' love;' that
goes without a
burden: do you sing it, and I'll
dance it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ye light o' love, with your heels!
then, if your
husband have stables enough,
you'll see he shall lack
no barns.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
O illegitimate construction! I scorn
that with
my heels.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; 'tis
time you
were ready. By my troth, I am exceeding
ill: heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: For the letter that begins them all, H.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Well, and you be not turned Turk,
there's no
more sailing by the star.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What means the fool, trow?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Nothing I; but God send every one
their heart's
desire!

sp.speaker: Hero.
Beat.
sp.p: I am stuffed, cousin; I cannot smell.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly
catching of
cold.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
O, God help me! God help me! how
long have
you professed apprehension?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Ever since you left it. Doth not my
wit become
me rarely?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is not seen enough, you should
wear it in
your cap. By my troth, I am sick.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Get you some of this distilled Carduus
Benedictus,
and lay it to your heart: it
is the only thing for a qualm.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Benedictus! why Benedictus? you
have some moral
in this Benedictus.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Moral! no, by my troth, I have no
moral meaning;
I meant, plain holy-thistle.
You may think perchance
that I think you are
in love: nay, by'r lady, I am not
such a fool to
think what I list, nor I list not to think
what I
can, nor indeed I cannot think, if I would
think
my heart out of thinking, that you are in
love or that you
will be in love or that you can
be in love. Yet Benedick
was such another,
and now is he become a man: he swore
he
would never marry, and yet now, in despite of
his
heart, he eats his meat without grudging:
and how you
may be converted I know not, but
methinks you look
with your eyes as other
women do.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Not a false gallop.
Re-enter URSULA.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
Madam, withdraw: the prince, the
count, Signior
