Benedick, Don John, and all the
gallants of the
town, are come to fetch you to
church.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
Help to dress me, good coz, good
Meg,
good Ursula.[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE V
div2.stage: Enter LEONATO, with DOGBERRY and VERGES.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
What would you with me, honest
neighbor?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, I would have some confidence
with you that decerns you nearly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a
busy time
with me.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Marry, this it is, sir.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What is it, my good friends?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little
off the
matter: an old man, sir, and his wits
are not so blunt as,
God help, I would desire
they were; but, in faith, honest
as the skin between
his brows.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Yes, I thank God I am as honest as
any man living
that is an old man and no
honester than I.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Comparisons are odorous: palabras,
neighbor
Verges.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Neighbors, you are tedious.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
It pleases your worship to say so, but
we are
the poor duke's officers; but truly, for
mine own part,
if I were as tedious as a king,
I could find it in my heart to
bestow it all of
your worship.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound
more
than 'tis; for I hear as good exclamation
on your worship
as of any man in the city;
and though I be but a
poor man, I am glad to
hear it.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I would fain know what you have to say.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, our watch to-night, excepting
your
worship's presence, ha' ta'en a
couple of as arrant
knaves as any in Messina.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
A good old man, sir; he will be talking:
as
they say, When the age is in, the wit is
out: God help us!
it is a world to see. Well
said, i' faith, neighbor Verges:
well, God's a
good man; an two men ride of a horse,
one
must ride behind. An honest soul, i' faith, sir;
by my
troth he is, as ever broke bread; but
God is to be worshipped;
all men are not
alike; alas, good neighbor!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Indeed, neighbor, he comes too short
of you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Gifts that God gives.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
One word, sir: our watch, sir, have
indeed
comprehended two aspicious persons,
and we would have
them this morning examined
before your worship.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Take their examination yourself and
bring it
me: I am now in great haste, as it
may appear unto you.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: It shall be suffigance.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Drink some wine ere you go: fare
you well.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
My lord, they stay for you to give
your
daughter to her husband.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll wait upon them: I am ready. [Exeunt Leonato and Messenger.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Go, good partner, go, get you to
Francis Seacole;
bid him bring his pen and
inkhorn to the gaol:
we are now to examination
these men.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: And we must do it wisely.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
We will spare for no wit, I warrant
you;
here's that shall drive some of them to a
noncome: only
get the learned writer to set
down our excommunication
and meet me at
the gaol. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I

stage.about: [ d.-pedro. d.-john. leon. friar. claud. bene. hero. beat.]

div2.stage:
Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,
HERO, BEATRICE, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Come, Friar Francis, be brief; only
to the
plain form of marriage, and you shall
recount their particular
duties afterwards.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
You come hither, my lord, to marry
this lady.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
To be married to her: friar, you
come to marry
her.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
Lady, you come hither to be married
to this
count.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p:
If either of you know any inward
impediment
why you should not be conjoined,
I charge you, on your
souls, to utter it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Know you any, Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: None, my lord.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Know you any, count?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I dare make his answer, none.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
O, what men dare do! what men
may do! what
men daily do, not knowing
what they do!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
How now! interjections? Why,
then, some be
of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Stand thee by, friar. Father, by your leave:
Will you with free and unconstrained soul
Give me this maid, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And what have I to give you back, whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Nothing, unless you render her again.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Sweet prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.
There, Leonato, take her back again:
Give not this rotten orange to your friend;
She's but the sign and semblance of her honor.
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O, what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood as modest evidence
To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,
All you that see her, that she were a maid,
By these exterior shows? But she is none:
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What do you mean, my lord?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof,
Have vanquish'd the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginity,���

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the 'forehand sin:
No, Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large;
But, as a brother to his sister, show'd
Bashful sincerity and comely love.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And seem'd I ever otherwise to you?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it:
You seem to me as Dian in her orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown;
But you are more intemperate in your blood
Than Venus, or those pamper'd animals
That rage in savage sensuality.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sweet prince, why speak not you?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: What should I speak?
I stand dishonor'd, that have gone about
To link my dear friend to a common stale.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: This looks not like a nuptial.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: True! O God!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the prince? is this the prince's brother?
Is this face Hero's? are our eyes our own?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: All this is so: but what of this, my lord?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Let me but move one question to your daughter;
And, by that fatherly and kindly power
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: O, God defend me! how am I beset!
What kind of catechising call you this?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: To make you answer truly to your name.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name
With any just reproach?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Marry, that can Hero;
Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue.
What man was he talk'd with you yesternight
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: I talk'd with no man at that hour, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Why, then are you no maiden. Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear: upon mine honor,
Myself, my brother and this grieved count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber-window
Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,
Confess'd the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Fie, fie! they are not to be named, my lord,
Not to be spoke of;
There is not chastity enough in language
Without offence to utter them. Thus, pretty lady,
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been,
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! farewell,
Thou pure impiety and impious purity!
For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love,
And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me? [Hero swoons.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?

sp.speaker: D. John.
sp.l: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up. [Exeunt Don Pedro, Don John, and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: How doth the lady?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Dead, I think. Help, uncle!
Hero! why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand.
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wish'd for.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: How now, cousin Hero!

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Have comfort, lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Dost thou look up?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Yea, wherefore should she not?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?
Do not live, Hero; do not ope thine eyes:
For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,
Strike at thy life. Grieved I, I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugal nature's frame?
O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggar's issue at my gates,
Who smirch'd thus and mired with infamy,
I might have said 'No part of it is mine;
This shame derives itself from unknown loins'?
But mine and mine I loved and mine I praised
And mine that I was proud on, mine so much
That I myself was to myself not mine,
Valuing of her,���why, she, O, she is fallen
Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again
And salt too little which may season give
To her foul-tainted flesh!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Sir, sir, be patient.

For my part, I am so attired
in wonder,
I know not what to say,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: O, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No, truly not; although, until last night,
I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Confirm'd, confirm'd! O, that is stronger made
Which was before barr'd up with ribs of iron!
Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so, that, speaking of her foulness,
Wash'd it with tears? Hence from her! let her die.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Hear me a little; for I have only been

Silent so
long and given way unto
This course of fortune....

By noting
of the lady I have mark'd
A thousand blushing apparitions
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames
In angel whiteness beat away those blushes;
And in her eye there hath appear'd a fire,
To burn the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool;
Trust not my reading nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenor of my book; trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here
Under some biting error.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Friar, it cannot be.
Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left
Is that she will not add to her damnation
A sin of perjury; she not denies it:
Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse
That which appears in proper nakedness?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: They know that do accuse me; I know none:
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy! O my father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintain'd the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Two of them have the very bent of honor;
And if their wisdoms be misled in this,
The practice of it lives in John the bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villanies.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know not. If they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,
Nor age so eat up my invention,
Nor fortune made such havoc of my means,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb and policy of mind,
Ability in means and choice of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Pause awhile,
And let my counsel sway you in this case.
Your daughter here the princes left for dead:
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it that she is dead indeed;
Maintain a mourning ostentation
And on your family's old monument
Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites
That appertain unto a burial.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What shall become of this? what will this do?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf
Change slander to remorse; that is some good:
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth.
She dying, as it must be so maintain'd,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied and excused
Of every hearer: for it so falls out
That what we have we prize not to the worth
Whiles we enjoy it, but being lack'd and lost,
Why, then we rack the value, then we find
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio:
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
The idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination,
And every lovely organ of her life
Shall come apparell'd in more precious habit,
More moving-delicate and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul,
Than when she lived indeed; then shall he mourn,
If ever love had interest in his liver,
And wish he had not so accused her,
No, though he thought his accusation true.
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape
Than I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be levell'd false,
The supposition of the lady's death
Will quench the wonder of her infamy:
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds and injuries.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you:
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honor, I will deal in this
As secretly and justly as your soul
Should with your body.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: 'Tis well consented: presently away;
For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.
Come, lady, die to live: this wedding-day
Perhaps is but prolong'd: have patience and endure. [Exeunt all but Benedick and Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I will not desire that.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You have no reason; I do it freely.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ah, how much might the man deserve
of me
that would right her!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is there any way to show such friendship?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: A very even way, but no such friend.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: May a man do it?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: It is a man's office, but not yours.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I do love nothing in the world so
well as you:
is not that strange?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
As strange as the thing I know not. It
were as
possible for me to say I loved nothing
so well as you: but
believe me not; and yet I
lie not; I confess nothing, nor
I deny nothing.
I am sorry for my cousin.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Do not swear, and eat it.

sp.speaker: Bene.
Beat.
sp.p: Will you not eat your word?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
With no sauce that can be devised to
it. I protest
I love thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why, then, God forgive me!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: What offence, sweet Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You have stayed me in a happy
hour: I was about
to protest I loved you.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: And do it with all thy heart.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I love you with so much of my heart
that none
is left to protest.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Come, bid me do any thing for thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Kill Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Ha! not for the wide world.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I am gone, though I am here: there
is no love
in you: nay, I pray you, let me go.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Beatrice,���

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: In faith, I will go.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: We'll be friends first.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You dare easier be friends with me
than fight
with mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is Claudio thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Is he not approved in the height a,
villain, that
hath slandered, scorned, dishonored
my kinswoman? O
that I were a man!
What, bear her in hand until they
come to take
hands; and then, with public accusation,
uncovered
slander, unmitigated rancor,���O God,
that I
were a man! I would eat his heart in the
market-place.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Hear me, Beatrice,���

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Talk with a man out at a window! A
proper
saying!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Nay, but, Beatrice,���

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Sweet Hero! She is wronged, she is
slandered,
she is undone.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Beat���

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Princes and counties! Surely, a
princely testimony,
a goodly count, Count
Comfect; a sweet gallant, surely!
O that I
were a man for his sake! or that I had any
friend would be a man for my sake! But manhood
is melted
into courtesies, valor into compliment,
and men are
only turned into tongue,
and trim ones too: he is now
a valiant as
Hercules that only tells a lie and swears it.
I
cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will
die a woman
with grieving.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Use it for my love some other way
than swearing
by it.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Think you in your soul the Count
Claudio
hath wronged Hero?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Enough, I am engaged; I will challenge
him. I
will kiss your hand, and so I
leave you. By this hand, Claudio
shall render
me a dear account. As you hear of me,
so
think of me. Go, comfort your cousin: I must
say she
is dead: and so, farewell. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage: Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and Sexton, in gowns; and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: O, a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: Which be the malefactors?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Marry, that am I and my partner.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Nay, that's certain; we have the exhibition
to examine.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
But which are the offenders that are
to be examined?
let them come before master
constable.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Yea, marry, let them come before
me. What is
your name, friend?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Borachio.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Pray, write down, Borachio. Yours,
sirrah?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I am a gentleman, sir, and my name
is Conrade.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Write down, master gentleman Conrade.
Masters,
do you serve God?

sp.speaker: Con. Bora.
sp.p: Yea, sir, we hope.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Write down, that they hope they
serve God: and write God first; for God defend
but God should go before such villains!
Masters, it is proved already
that you are little
better than false knaves; and it will go
near to
be thought so shortly. How answer you for
yourselves ?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry, sir, we say we are none.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
A marvellous witty fellow, I assure
you: but I
will go about with him. Come you
hither, sirrah; a word
in your ear: sir, I say
to you, it is thought you are false
knaves.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Sir, I say to you we are none.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Well, stand aside. 'Fore God, they
are both in
a tale. Have you writ down, that
they are none?

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
Master constable, you go not the way
to examine:
you must call forth the watch
that are their
accusers.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Yea, marry, that's the eftest way. Let
the watch
come forth. Masters, I charge you,
in the prince's name,
accuse these men.

sp.speaker: First Watch.
sp.p:
This man said, sir, that Don
John, the prince's
brother, was a villain.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Write down Prince John a villain.
Why, this
is flat perjury, to call a prince's
brother villain.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Master constable,���

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Pray thee, fellow, peace: I do not
like thy look,
I promise thee.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: What heard you him say else?

sp.speaker: Sec. Watch.
sp.p:
Marry, that he had received
thousand ducats
of Don John for accusing the
Lady Hero
wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: Yea, by mass, that it is.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: What else, fellow?

sp.speaker: First Watch.
sp.p:
And that Count Claudio did
mean, upon his
words, to disgrace Hero before
the whole assembly, and
not marry her.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
O villain! thou wilt be condemned
into everlasting
redemption for this.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p:
And this is more, masters, than you
can deny.
Prince John is this morning secretly
stolen away; Hero
was in this manner accused,
in this very manner refused,
and upon
the grief of this suddenly died. Master constable,
let these men be bound, and brought to
Leonato's:
I will go before and show him
their examination.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Come, let them be opinioned.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p: Let them be in the hands���

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Off, coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
God's my life, where's the sexton?
let him write
down the prince's officer coxcomb.
Come, bind them.
Thou naughty varlet!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Away! you are an ass, you are an ass.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Dost thou not suspect my place? dost
thou not
suspect my years? O that he were
here to write me
down an ass! But, masters,
remember that I am an ass;
though it be not
written down, yet forget not that I am an
ass.
No, thou villain, thou art full of piety, as shall
be proved
upon thee by good witness. I am a
wise fellow, and,
which is more, an officer, and,
which is more, a householder,
and, which is
more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in
Messina, and one that knows the law, go to;
and a rich
fellow enough, go to; and a fellow
that hath had losses,
and one that hath two
gowns and every thing handsome
about him.
Bring him away. O that I had been writ
down
an ass! [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself:
And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief
Against yourself.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I pray thee, cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless
As water in a sieve: give not me counsel;
Nor let no comforter delight mine ear
But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelm'd like mine,
And bid him speak of patience;
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form:
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
Bid sorrow wag, cry 'hem!' when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk
With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience.
But there is no such man: for, brother, men
Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief
Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion, which before
Would give preceptial medicine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air and agony with words:
No, no; 'tis all men's office to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow,
But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral when he shall endure
The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel:
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood;
For there was never yet philosopher
That could endure the toothache patiently,
However they have writ the style of gods
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself;
Make those that do offend you suffer too.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There thou speak'st reason: nay, I will do so.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;
And that shall Claudio know; so shall the prince
And all of them that thus dishonor her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here comes the prince and Claudio hastily. Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Good den, good den.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Good day to both of you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hear you, my lords,���

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: We have some haste, Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Some haste, my lord! well, fare you well, my lord:
Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If he could right himself with quarrelling,
Some of us would lie low.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Who wrongs him?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou:���
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword;
I fear thee not.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Marry, beshrew my hand,
If it should give your age such cause of fear:
In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tush, tush, man; never fleer and jest at me:
I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag
What I have done being young, or what would do
Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,
Thou hast so wrong'd mine innocent child and me
That I am forced to lay my reverence by
And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days,
Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child;
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors;
O, in a tomb where never scandal slept,
Save this of hers, framed by thy villany!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: My villany?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: You say not right, old man.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My lord, my lord,
I'll prove it on his body, if he dare,
Despite his nice fence and his active practice,
His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Away! I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast kill'd my child:
If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed:
But that's no matter; let him kill one first;
Win me and wear me; let him answer me.
Come, follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come, follow me:
Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence;
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Brother,���

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece;
And she is dead, slander'd to death by villains,
That dare as well answer a man indeed
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue:
Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Brother Anthony,���

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,���
Scrambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boys,
That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,
Go anticly, show outward hideousness,
And speak off half a dozen dangerous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst;
And this is all.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: But, brother Anthony,���

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, 'tis no matter:
Do not you meddle; let me deal in this.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
My heart is sorry for your daughter's death:
But, on my honor, she was charged with nothing
But what was true and very full of proof.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My lord, my lord,���

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And shall, or some of us will smart for it. [Exeunt Leonato and Antonio

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: See, see; here comes the man we went to seek. Enter BENEDICK.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Now, signior, what news?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Good day, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Welcome, signior: you are almost
come to part
almost a fray.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
We had like to have had our two
noses snapped
off with two old men without
teeth.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Leonato and his brother. What
thinkest thou? Had
we fought, I doubt we
should have been too young for
them.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In a false quarrel there is no true
valor. I came
to seek you both.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
We have been up and down to seek
thee; for
we are high-proof melancholy and
would fain have it
beaten away. Wilt thou
use thy wit?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: It is in my scabbard: shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Dost thou wear thy wit by thy
side?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Never any did so, though very many
have been
beside their wit. I will bid thee draw,
as we do the minstrels;
draw, to pleasure us.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
As I am an honest man, he looks
pale. Art thou
sick, or angry?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
What, courage, man! What though
care killed a
cat, thou hast mettle enough in
thee to kill care.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career,
and
you charge it against me. I pray you
choose another
subject.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Nay, then, give him another staff:
this last was
broke cross.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
By this light, he changes more
and more: I think
he be angry indeed.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: God bless me from a challenge!

div2.sp:
Bene.[Aside to Claudio]
You are a villain;
I jest not: I will make it good
how you
dare, with what you dare, and when you dare.
Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice.
You have
killed a sweet lady, and her death
shall fall heavy on
you. Let me hear from
you.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Well, I will meet you, so I may
have good
cheer.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: What, a feast, a feast?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I' faith, I thank him; he hath bid
me to a calf's
head and a capon; the which
if I do not carve most curiously,
say my knife's
naught. Shall I not find a woodcock
too?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised
thy wit the other
day. I said, thou hadst a
fine wit: 'True,' said she, 'a fine
little one.'
'No,' said I, 'a great wit:' 'Right,' says she,
'a great
gross one.' 'Nay,' said I, 'a good
wit:' 'Just,' said she, 'it hurts
nobody.'
'Nay,' said I, 'the gentleman is wise:' 'Certain,'
said
she,'a wise gentleman.' 'Nay,' said
I, 'he hath the tongues:'
'That I believe,'
said she, 'for he swore a thing to me on
Monday
night, which he forswore on Tuesday
morning;
there's a double tongue; there's two
tongues.' Thus did
she, an hour, together, transshape
thy particular virtues:
yet at last she
concluded with a sigh, thou wast the
properest
man in Italy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
For the which she wept heartily
and said she
cared not.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Yea, that she did: but yet, for
all that, an if she
did not hate him deadly, she
would love him dearly:
the old man's daughter
told us all.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
All, all; and, moreover, God saw
him when he
was hid in the garden.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
But when shall we set the savage
bull's horns
on the sensible Benedick's head?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Yea, and text underneath, 'Here
dwells Benedick
the married man'?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Fare you well, boy: you know my
mind. I will
leave you now to your gossiplike
humor: you break
jests as braggards do
their blades, which God be thanked,
hurt not.
My lord, for your many courtesies I thank
you: I must discontinue your company: your
brother
the bastard is fled from Messina: you
have among you
killed a sweet and innocent
lady. For my Lord Lackbeard
there, he and
I shall meet: and, till then, peace be
with him. [Exit.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: He is in earnest.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
In most profound earnest; and, I'll
warrant you,
for the love of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p: And hath challenged thee.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
What a pretty thing man is when
he goes in his
doublet and hose and leaves off
his wit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
He is then a giant to an ape; but
then is an ape
a doctor to such a man.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
But, soft you, let me be: pluck
up, my heart, and
be sad. Did he not say, my
brother was fled? Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Come you, sir: if justice cannot tame
you, she
shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her
balance: nay, an
you be a cursing hypocrite
once, you must be looked to.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
How now? two of my brother's
men bound! Borachio
one!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Hearken after their offence, my lord.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Officers, what offence have these
men done?

sp.speaker: Dog.
D. Pedro.
sp.p:
First, I ask thee what they have
done; thirdly,
I ask thee what's their offence;
sixth and lastly, why they
are committed; and,
to conclude, what you lay to their
charge.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Rightly reasoned, and in his own
division: and,
by my troth, there's one meaning
well suited.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
Who have you offended, masters,
that you are
thus bound to your answer? this
learned constable is too
cunning to be understood:
what's your offence?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Sweet prince, let me go no farther to
mine answer:
do you hear me, and let this
count kill me. I
have deceived even your very
eyes: what your wisdoms
could not discover,
these shallow fools have
brought to light: who
in the night overheard me confessing
to this
man how Don John your brother incensed
me
to slander the Lady Hero, how you were
brought
into the orchard and saw me court
Margaret in Hero's
garments, how you disgraced
her, when you should
marry her: my
villany they have upon record; which
I had
rather seal with my death than repeat over to
my shame. The lady is dead upon mine and
my master's
false accusation; and, briefly, I
desire nothing but the
reward of a villain.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l:
Runs not this speech like iron through your
blood?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I have drunk poison whiles he utter'd it.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: But did my brother set thee on to this?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p:
Yea, and paid me richly for the
practice of it.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: He is composed and framed of treachery:
And fled he is upon this villany.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Sweet Hero! now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by
this time
our sexton hath reformed Signior
Leonato of the matter:
and, masters, do not
forget to specify, when time and place
shall
serve, that I am an ass.

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Here, here comes master Signior Leonato,
and
the Sexton too.
Re-enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, with the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes,
That, when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him: which of these is he?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l:
Art thou the slave that with thy breath
hast kill'd
Mine innocent child?

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: Yea, even I alone.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No, not so, villain; thou beliest thyself:
Here stand a pair of honorable men;
A third is fled, that had a hand in it.
I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death:
Record it with your high and worthy deeds:
'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I know not how to pray your patience;
Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself;
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin: yet sinn'd I not
But in mistaking.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: By my soul, nor I:
And yet, to satisfy this good old man,
I would bend under any heavy weight
That he'll enjoin me to.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live;
That were impossible: but, I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here
How innocent she died; and if your love
Can labor ought in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb
And sing it to her bones, sing it to-night:
To-morrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that's dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us:
Give her the right you should have given heir cousin,
And so dies my revenge.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O noble sir,
Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me!
I do embrace your offer; and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To-morrow then I will expect your coming;
To-night I take my leave. This naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was pack'd in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.l: No, by my soul, she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous
In any thing that I do know by her.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Moreover, sir, which indeed is not
under white
and black, this plaintiff here, the
offender, did call me
ass: I beseech you, let it
be remembered in his punishment.
And also,
the watch heard them talk of one Deformed:
they say he wears a key in his ear and a lock
hanging
by it, and borrows money in God's
name, the which
he hath used so long and
never paid that now men grow
hard-hearted
and will lend nothing for God's sake: pray
you, examine him upon that point.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Your worship speaks like a most
thankful
and reverend youth; and I praise
God for you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There's for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.l: God save the foundation!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner,
and I
thank thee.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
I leave an arrant knave with your
worship;
which I beseech your worship to
correct yourself, for
the example of others.
God keep your worship! I
wish your worship
well; God restore you to health!
I humbly
give you leave to depart; and if a merry
meeting
may be wished, God prohibit it! Come,
neighbor. [Exeunt Dogberry and Verges.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l:
Farewell, my lords: we look for you
to-morrow.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: To-night I'll mourn with Hero.

div2.sp:
Leon.[To the Watch]
Bring you these fellows on. We'll talk with
Margaret,
How her acquaintance grew with this lewd
fellow. [Exeunt, severally.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret,
deserve
well at my hands by helping me to
the speech of
Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Will you then write me a sonnet in
praise of
my beauty?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In so high a style, Margaret, that no
man living
shall come over it; for, in most
comely truth, thou deservest
it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
To have no man come over me!
why, shall I always
keep below stairs?

sp.speaker: Bene.
Marg.
sp.p:
And yours as blunt as the fencer's
foils, which
hit, but hurt not.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
A most manly wit, Margaret; it will
not hurt a
woman: and so, I pray thee, call
Beatrice: I give thee the
bucklers.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Give us the swords; we have bucklers
of our
own.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If you use them, Margaret, you must
put in the
pikes with a vice; and they are
dangerous weapons for
maids.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Well, I will call Beatrice to you,
who I think
hath legs.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: And therefore will come. [Exit Margaret. [Sings]

lg.l: And knows me, and knows me,

sp.p:
I mean in singing; but in loving, Leander
the
good swimmer, Troilus the first employer of
pandars, and a whole bookful of these quondam
carpet-mongers,
whose names yet run
smoothly in the even
road of a blank verse,
why, they were never so truly
turned over and
over as my poor self in love. Marry,
I cannot
show it in rhyme; I have tried: I can find out
no
rhyme to 'lady' but 'baby,' an innocent
rhyme; for 'scorn,'
'horn,' a hard rhyme;
for, 'school,' 'fool,' a babbling rhyme;
very
ominous endings: no, I was not born under a
rhyming
planet, nor I cannot woo in festival
terms.
Enter BEATRICE.

Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I
called
thee?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yea, signior, and depart when you bid me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: O, stay but till then!

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
'Then' is spoken; fare you well
now: and yet, ere
I go, let me go with that I
came; which is, with knowing
what hath
passed between you and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Only foul words; and thereupon I
will kiss
thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Foul words is but foul wind, and foul
wind
is but foul breath, and foul breath is
noisome; therefore
I will depart unkissed.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Thou hast frighted the word out of
his right
sense, so forcible is thy wit. But I
must tell thee plainly,
Claudio undergoes my
challenge; and either I must shortly
hear from
him, or I will subscribe him a coward. And,
I
pray thee now, tell me for which of my bad
parts didst
thou first fall in love with me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
For them all together; which maintained
so
politic a state of evil that they will
not admit any
good part to intermingle with
them. But for which of
my good parts did
you first suffer love for me?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Suffer love! a good epithet! I do
suffer love indeed,
for I love thee against my
will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
In spite of your heart, I think; alas,
poor heart!
If you spite it for my sake, I will
spite it for yours; for
I will never love that
which my friend hates.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Thou and I are too wise to woo
peaceably.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It appears not in this confession:
there's not one
wise man among twenty that
will praise himself.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
An old, an old instance, Beatrice,
that lived in
the time of good neighbors. If a
man do not erect in
this age his own tomb ere
he dies, he shall live no
longer in monument
than the bell rings and the widow
weeps.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And how long is that, think you?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Question: why, an hour in clamor
and a quarter
in rheum: therefore is it most
expedient for the wise,
if Don Worm, his conscience,
find no impediment to
the contrary, to
be the trumpet of his own virtues, as
I am to
myself. So much for praising myself, who, I
myself
will bear witness, is praiseworthy: and
now tell
me, how doth your cousin?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Very ill.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: And how do you?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Very ill too.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Serve God, love me and mend. There
will I leave
you too, for here comes one in
haste. Enter URSULA.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
Madam, you must come to your uncle.
Yonder's
old coil at home: it is proved
my Lady Hero
hath been falsely accused, the
prince and Claudio
mightily abused; and Don
John is the author of all, who
is fled and gone.
Will you come presently?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Will you go hear this news, signior?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I will live in thy heart, die in thy
lap and be buried
in thy eyes; and moreover
sp.l:
I will go with thee to
thy uncle's. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and three or four with tapers.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Is this the monument of Leonato?
It is, my lord.

div2.sp:
Claud. [Reading out of a scroll]
Done to death by slanderous tongues
Was the Hero that here lies:
Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies.
So the life that died with shame
Lives in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dumb.
Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.
SONG.
Pardon, goddess of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight;
For the which, with songs of woe,
Round about her tomb they go.
Midnight, assist our moan;
Help us to sigh and groan,
Heavily, heavily:
Graves, yawn and yield your dead,
Till death be uttered,
Heavily, heavily.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Now, unto thy bones good night!
Yearly will I do this rite.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Good morrow, masters; put your torches out:
The wolves have prey'd; and look, the gentle day,
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.
Thanks to you all, and leave us: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Good morrow, masters: each his several way.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds;
And then to Leonato's we will go.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And Hymen now with luckier issue speed's
Than this for whom we render'd up this woe. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE IV

stage.about: [ leon. ant. bene. beat. marg. urs. friar. hero.]

div2.stage: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, BENEDICK, BEATRICE, MARGARET, URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, and HERO.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: So are the prince and Claudio, who accused her
Upon the error that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will, as it appears
In the true course of all the question.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: And so am I, being else by faith enforced
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you, come hither mask'd. [Exeunt Ladies.
The prince and Claudio promised by this hour
To visit me. You know your office, brother:
You must be father to your brother's daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Which I will do with confirm'd countenance.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: To do what, signior?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: To bind me, or undo me; one of them.
Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favor.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That eye my daughter lent her: 'tis most true.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio and the prince: but what's your will?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical:
But, for my will, my will is your good will
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd
In the state of honorable marriage:
In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My heart is with your liking.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: And my help.

Here comes the prince and Claudio.
Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO, and two or three others.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Good morrow, prince; good morrow, Claudio;
We here attend you. Are you yet determined
To-day to marry with my brother's daughter?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I'll hold my mind, were she an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Call her forth, brother; here's the friar ready. [Exit Antonio.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter,
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.
Tush, fear not, man; we'll tip thy horns with gold
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Jove,
When he would play the noble beast in love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low;
And some such strange bull leap'd your father's cow,
And got a calf in that same noble feat
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings. Re-enter ANTONIO, with the Ladies masked.
Which is the lady I must seize upon?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This same is she, and I do give you her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Why, then she's mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No, that you shall not, till you take her hand
Before this friar and swear to marry her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Give me your hand: before this holy friar,
I am your husband, if you like of me.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And when I lived, I was your other wife: [Unmasking.
And when you loved, you were my other husband.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Another Hero!

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Nothing certainer:
One Hero died defiled, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.l: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: All this amazement can I qualify;
When after that the holy rites are ended,
I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death:
Meantime let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

div2.sp:
Beat. [Unmasking]
I answer to that name. What is your will?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why, no; no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Why, then your uncle and the prince and Claudio
Have been deceived; they swore you did.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Troth, no; no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why, then my cousin Margaret and Ursula
Are much deceived; for they did swear you did.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: And I'll be sworn upon't that he loves her;
For here's a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashion'd to Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And here's another
Writ in my cousin's hand, stolen from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedick.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
A miracle! here's our own hands

against our 
hearts. Come, I will have thee;

but, by this light, I take 
thee for pity.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I would not deny you; but, by this
good day, I
yield upon great persuasion; and
partly to save your life,
for I was told you
were in a consumption.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Peace! I will stop your mouth. [Kissing her.

sp.speaker: D. Pedro.
sp.p:
How dost thou, Benedick, the
married man?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I'll tell thee what, prince; a college
of wit-crackers
cannot flout me out of my
humor. Dost thou
think I care for a satire or
an epigram? No: if a man will
be beaten
with brains, a' shall wear nothing handsome
about him. In brief, since I do purpose to
marry, I will
think nothing to any purpose
that the world can say against
it; and therefore
never flout at me for what I have said
against it; for man is a giddy thing, and this
is my conclusion.
For thy part, Claudio, I did
think to have beaten
thee; but in that thou
art like to be my kinsman, live unbruised
and
love my cousin.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
I had well hoped thou wouldst have
denied Beatrice, that
I might have cudgelled
thee out of thy single life, to make
thee a
double-dealer; which, out of question, thou
wilt be,
if my cousin do not look exceedingly
narrowly to thee.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Come, come, we are friends: let's
have a dance
ere we are married, that we may
lighten our own hearts
and our wives' heels.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: We'll have dancing afterward.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
First, of my word; therefore play,
music. Prince,
thou art sad; get thee a wife,
get thee a wife: there is no
staff more reverend
than one tipped with horn.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight,
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Think not on him till to-morrow:

I'll devise
thee brave punishments for him.
Strike up, pipers. [Dance. [Exeunt.
